Title: A Universe Within
Content:
This artwork, titled A Universe Within, explores the theme of “shelter” through a deeply personal lens, reflecting my lived experiences of being bedbound and housebound. The piece represents the act of transforming a place of confinement into a space of imagination, healing, and wonder.
 
 
 
 The illuminated canopy, celestial hues, and angelic figures symbolise the universe I created within my bed—a sanctuary where creativity thrived despite physical limitations. By blending ethereal, dreamlike visuals with the concept of refuge, this work celebrates the resilience of the human spirit in seeking comfort and beauty even in challenging circumstances. It invites the viewer to consider the profound relationship between physical spaces and emotional wellbeing, and how “shelter” can be both a literal and figurative source of solace.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
This artwork reflects my personal experience of being bedbound and housebound, where my bed became both a physical and emotional shelter. The illuminated canopy and celestial hues represent the universe I created within this confined space, transforming it into a place of imagination, healing, and escape. The angelic figures symbolise protection and comfort, echoing the sense of safety I sought during these periods.
 
 
 
 Through its dreamlike aesthetic, the piece explores how shelter is not just a physical structure but a state of mind—a sanctuary where we find solace and resilience. It invites viewers to reflect on the ways we create personal havens in challenging times, finding beauty and meaning in the spaces that hold us. By merging themes of vulnerability and creativity, the work underscores how shelter nurtures both our bodies and spirits.

Title: Listening
Content:
Paper mache, biro, ink, gouache on gesso. (12 x 22 approx.)
 
 
 
 (the artwork is hollow + has detail inside)
 
 Autobiographical work exploring social class. Made to the size of a British brick, the work is an exaggerated hybrid to listening, and the artists psychological reflection on their childhood in the West-Midlands surrounding housing + the human side to home.
 
 
 
 Where distracted playfulness and imagination bleed into walls, constantly stripping back the past frustration and fragility of repeated systems. Marking a working-class familiarity with council neighbourhood’s + industrial material. 
 
 Asking…is anyone really Listening?

Title: Welcome Home
Content: This drawing is of what the word 'shelter' means to me - a place of safety and security, a place which is familiar, welcoming and always safe, where everyone is always glad to see me, where it is warm and cosy and friendly. The forest here is home to all my favourite things such as cakes and chocolate, biscuits and Blackpool Tower, Belisha Beacons playing with a ball, the Moon, slices of bread, cups of tea, hats and crocs and spoons and many other friendly characters all around, some you can't even see, and we all live here safe and happy. Whenever I return from having to venture out into what others consider the 'real' world, I am so glad to come back Home and be welcomed by all of my friends. The trees are the overarching guardians protecting us from storms and always happy to chat, share stories or just listen whilst you lean against them. This place of shelter gives me immense comfort whilst I navigate the uncertain world I live in, and the challenges I face every day as a very late diagnosed Autistic woman with ADHD and EDS

Content: This is icon, inspired by medieval early Christianity art,made on wooden panel ,egg tempera and water guilding.Presents fundamental principle of Christianity,where the Church is built on holy martyrs sacrifice.Here is depicted event in 302.where 20 thousand of Christians were in Nicomidia on Christmas Day burned in church .Icon present transfigured reality, already in eschatology,so everything shine with victory and hope. Title: Tree Tunnels - A Story of Sheltering
Content:
A record of a walk.
 
 
 
 I am inspired by liminal spaces, our native plants, wildlife and local landscape. As someone with a chronic illness and physical disability, walking is a challenge. My ability to do so can change suddenly and with little warning. The tree tunnels I explored for the project are close to home.
 
 
 
 
 
 I love the feelings of being enveloped and the protection these places bring me. They have shielded me during sudden downpours, and provide shelter for the plants and animals which inspire my art.
 
 
 
 
 
 See the tree tunnels behind the story and see how I eco-printed the fabric :
 
 https://www.instagram.com/reel/DCNZvk8ij3k/?igsh=MXFoODBvYjQ4N3d4Yg==
 
 
 
 
 
 The piece is a visual representation of how these tree tunnels make me feel, particularly during late autumn and this artwork, like every artwork I make, began with a local walk.
 
 
 
 
 
 The mixed-media collage combines a variety of papers - mostly semi-transparent and rescued from the recycling bin, several types of cloth, hand stitching and a few other creative processes.
 
 
 
 
 
 Eco-printing provided the colour palette and leaf images, but it was also highly influenced by the soft, muted, ghostly shades I feel convey the atmosphere of misty mornings.
 
 
 
 
 
 A range of fabrics were used and all had a previous life. They were dyed in a few ways. Some were coloured with crushed red sandstone which I collected from the field near our home. I gathered juicy blue-black sloe berries and rosehips and processed them to create a dye. I also used black ink.
 
 
 
 
 
 Photos, drawings and real ferns were transferred onto semi-transparent papers by photocopying and other transfer methods and I used them for layering under and over over materials to create that ghostly effect I was after.
 
 
 
 
 
 Lastly, I attached leaf skeletons and sycamore seeds. Like the leaves used in the eco-printing process and the berries and rosehips used to create dyes, the sycamore seeds were also gathered from the tree tunnels. The leaf skeletons were extremely fragile so I sandwiched between thin teabag paper and adhered it using gloss gel medium. This strengthened them whilst maintaining their beautiful, delicate transparency which I love.
Material: Craft, Drawing, Embroidery, Mixed media, Painting, Photography, Print, Textiles
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
I am inspired by liminal spaces, native plants, wildlife and local landscape. As someone with a chronic illness, walking is a challenge. My ability to do so can change suddenly and with little warning. The tree tunnels I explored for the project are close to home. I love the feelings of envelopment and protection these places bring me. They have shielded me during sudden downpours, and provide shelter for the plants and animals which inspire my art.
 
 
 
 This is a visual representation of how the tree tunnels make me feel, particularly during late autumn. The mixed-media collage combines papers, cloth, hand stitching and other creative processes. Eco-printing provided the colour palette and leaf images. Fabrics have been dyed with sandstone, berries and ink. Photos, drawings and ferns were transferred onto semi-transparent papers. Lastly, I attached leaf skeletons and seeds I'd gathered.

Title: Shelter
Content:
Shelter means to me is a place where I feel safe, protected and comfortable. A feel of coziness, love, support and affection makes it a
 
 
 
 home. No matter, how small or big, permanent or temporary it is but there is an invisible string of attachment .
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 A place, where you feel mental and physical freedom defines it a safe haven. A life without any roof on your head is unimaginable. To offer someone shelter means that you are saving a life. I can understand that very well when in an incident in the middle of night me and my family had to spend a night in a mosque.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 In my artwork I symbolically used honeybees to raise the issue of serious declining of bee species in UK. Only by wearing bee emblem on our suits to show strong loving connection and support without any expectations is not enough. We have to protect them by providing shelter.

Title: The Protector
Content:
In my acrylic painting, "The Protector," I explore the intricate dynamics of the traditional male role within the family structure, focusing on the delicate balance of being a lover, provider and a protector. This painting is a visual exploration of these age-old expectations, that have defined men since the time of the cavemen.
 
 
 
 The concept of protection often extends beyond the physical realm, encompassing emotional and psychological support, which can be likened to the sanctuary that a shelter provides. In creating this piece, I wanted to reflect on the evolving nature of these roles in contemporary society, where partnerships are increasingly defined by mutual support and shared responsibilities.

Title: Longing
Content: I made this for the theme shelter. Shelter for me has a lot of mixed feelings and associations. I have spent a lot of time indoors as a result of my health and sometimes shelter can feel dark and colourless. My piece longing tries to express the darkness and plainness of indoors. The geese and trees in the window represent life going on outside.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I made this for the theme shelter. Shelter has many mixed feelings and associations for me. I have spent a lot of time indoors, due to my health, and sometimes shelter can feel dark and colourless. My piece longing tries to express the darkness and plainness of indoors. The geese and trees in the window represent life going on outside. The empty chair represents emptiness and the feeling of loss of yourself, of starting to question if you even exist. If other people can see you. I chose to use charcoal as a medium because it's so fragile and changes so easily, a lot like life.

Title: Sanctuary
Content: 3D standing piece made entirely from recycled materials and found objects. It is constructed from different parts including collages from my own drawings and paintings on the front and the back. The frame and the dome is decorated with fabrics and discarded trinkets.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
My artwork is a brand new piece and was made in mind with the theme of the exhibition. The construction represents a safe place where one can find peace amidst the chaos of everyday life. It's based on art's powerful effect on my health and wellbeing.
 
 The artwork has a religious undertone as a reference to my relationship with faith that is complicated and is something I take inspiration from in order to explore my own spirituality. Churches and places of worship used to serve as shelters throughout history in the physical and in the spiritual sense.
 
 The structure was made of multiple parts using discarded materials, found objects and my own drawings as part of my sustainable art practice.
 
 The artwork is full of symbolism, taking inspiration from my Hungarian heritage and rural upbringing, relationship with the natural world and my fascination with folk customs and traditions.

Title: Unfurl
Content: This embroidery, comprising cotton and linen thread and an embroidery needle on a found cotton doily, explores the motif of the snail, one I return to again and again. Snails can symbolise protection or armour (think of the depiction of knights duelling with snails in medieval manuscripts - here the threaded needle is held in the hand almost like a dagger), vulnerability, home and the idea of carrying home with you. Unfurling, retreating, unfurling again.

Title: I am your shelter
Content:
This large scale drawing in black sharpie aims to encapsulate some of my experience of pregnancy and beyond. Using subject matters of anatomy, I’m able to abstract and explore elements such as the incredible basket weave like muscle pattern of the womb, or intricate looking brain neurons. I have also included stages of the beautiful phenomenon that is micro chimera-where cells from the pregnant person, foetus and placenta move between each other. These new, transformed cells can remain with the mother for years to come; and vice versa.
 
 
 
 The drawing also contains the chemical structure of medicine as well as medical equipment...
 
 
 
 I was my son’s shelter throughout pregnancy, keeping him as safe as I could. This drawing explores a little beyond that, whereby I experienced post partum psychosis after he was born, requiring a new shelter for us both; a Mother and Baby Unit.

Title: Oignon (French for Onion)
Content: Neurodivergent people have to ‘mask’ (behaving like people expect us to) daily to fit in society. This is a representation of my own layers of masking and people-pleasing. To access the weirdness at the core which makes me ‘me’, you have to peel all the external layers first. That’s why I struggle to connect with people when meeting them for the first time. But sometimes, I meet another neurodivergent person similarly-wired and it clicks right away. Our core colours meet in fireworks.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:

Title: shelter
Content: multiplicity, solitude, freedom
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I made this artwork recently, returning to artmaking after a difficult year. This piece reflects on the nourishment and nurturing that is possible in safety and solitude, where multiplicity is inherent and the restrictive outer self falls away. As a queer, neurodivergent, trans person, the world can be a difficult place to inhabit. Intimate, domestic spaces like the bedroom, precarious and hard fought for, become life sustaining shelters and safe havens. This piece is a reminder to seek out space to relax, unmask, and heal without guilt or shame.

Title: Candala - Beacon
Content:
Reclaimed galvanised steel, plastic, aluminium, acrylic paint.
 
 As the name suggests, this mandala is made from empty spraycans. Panpsychists believe that consciousness exists within all matter including stone or metal. These cans carry a charge, a strong calling to commit a rebellious act of creation, smuggled covertly, idea formulated, hyper-aware, adrenaline pumping, and finally releasing the pressure. Walking along the tracks, sneaking into a train yard, exploring abandoned buildings, painting rooftops, dangling off bridges. Tales of lines crossed, and drawn on the landscape are stored within.
 
 It's recommended that these sculptures are hung 222 off the ground in order that they can offer maximum heart chakra activation based on yogic principles when audiences look up and subconsciously open up their heart space.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
Graffiti and street art have been my refuge since my teenage years—my beacon of hope, cathartic release, and the community of misfits to which I belong.
 
 
 
 It’s an underground network of outsider artists that transcends age, race, class, and geography. A shelter for those who don’t fit in, it’s a place where we claim ownership in an environment that often excludes us.
 
 
 
 For over half a century, our grassroots, working-class movement has thrived in the shadows, yet remains unseen. Despite its power as a safe haven, it is still unrecognized. I ask that it be acknowledged for what it truly is: a sanctuary for those who need it most.

Title: the washing line in my garden
Content: My garden is a very important place to me. Its home, its safety and sanctuary, nature, beauty, spirituality and refuge. I am very very fortunate to have this space to grow my plants and look at them in peace and quiet and meditate on my experience of life without having to go anywhere to do it and without having to be grateful to anyone else for the experience. It my experience and its not about getting anywhere or changing myself or trying to prove myself, its just about being. This is a rare and precious thing. For most of my life I didn't feel safe, I didn't feel safe to be and I didn't feel safe to be me and think my thoughts and be who I wanted to be. From this back ground the garden has been a refuge. When I look at washing on my line and colours of the washing and shapes of the leaves with the light of the sun making shapes and patterns everything else disappears, I am mesmerised. This painting is my attempt to capture all the magic colours and shapes.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: My garden is my shelter. Its the place I have been able to hide from the world after experiences that left me feeling it was unsafe to be me and the world was not a safe place to be. Being able to grow the plants high and sit on a small chair in amongst the growth has been a truly lifesaving experience over and over. Looking at all the different shades of green, at the textures and shapes and the light changing and glinting is mesmerising and magical. It has given me a sense of self when that had been taken over and over. When i saw my big pink towel on the line I fell in love with the whole scene and was determined to paint it... I could tell you a whole story about the towel, a whole story about the plant with the big leaves (macleaya cordata) or the plume poppy), I could tell you a whole story about how I came to discover painting. All of these things add up to being my shelter.

Title: Uproot
Content:
Uproot is a sculptural work created by weaving foraged Japanese honeysuckle from my local forest around my body and then onto a found mattress coil. This piece examines the duality of trauma—how it can simultaneously tether us to a place and evoke feelings of displacement and isolation.
 
 By exposing the unseen, internal structure of a mattress—a space associated with rest and intimacy—Uproot challenges us to reflect on how places meant for comfort can also harbor painful memories. The rusty, rigid coils, woven with the soft, natural honeysuckle, evoke the tension between vulnerability and resilience.
 
 The act of weaving becomes a meditative process of reclamation, transforming the cold, industrial frame into a protective shelter. This tactile process mirrors the journey of healing: reappropriating spaces tied to pain and finding refuge within oneself.
 
 By merging elements of nature with an object of domestic familiarity, Uproot explores how we create shelters—both physical and emotional—in the aftermath of trauma. It invites the viewer to consider how we reconstruct safety and belonging, even in spaces once defined by discomfort or harm.
 
 This work can be shown as a sculpture with complimentary photographs with my body inside the sculpture
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:

By revealing a mattress's internal structure—a space linked to rest and intimacy—Uproot challenges how comfort can coexist with pain. Rusted coils intertwined with soft honeysuckle embody vulnerability and resilience, reflecting trauma's complexities.
 
 The meditative weaving process reclaims the industrial frame, transforming it into a protective shelter. This act parallels healing—reappropriating painful spaces into sources of refuge. By merging natural and domestic elements, Uproot examines how we rebuild safety after trauma. It invites reflection on how we construct shelters—physical and emotional—in places once defined by discomfort, forging belonging and security amid vulnerabity

Title: Blanket
Content:
‘Blanket’ is constructed from discarded plastic packaging. The form of a blanket initially suggests protection, safety and shelter but it is not to be trusted.
 
 
 
 The colours and properties of the materials are used to create a textile piece, knitting together ’found’ resources . There is an element of chance in the way the colours and shapes build into a floppy abstract arrangement , coming together as a record of our use of resources at this time.
 
 
 
 As a functioning object, it is useless , with holes and loose, messy construction. It would provide no warmth or sense of shelter and would feel unpleasant against the skin. At best, it could act as sun shade but would start to degrade in the daylight.
 
 
 
 This ‘Blanket’ is an unreliable form of shelter, something to beware of, a mistake, a folly.

Title: Fulfillment
Content:
For me, shelter isn’t just a physical space—it’s a state of being. I find my true refuge in my art. This painting expresses the deep sense of safety and solace I experience when I paint. It’s a space where I can create freely, guided by my instincts and unburdened by the expectations of society. My art is my sanctuary, offering me protection from the barriers I often face in the world.
 
 
 
 In society, I frequently encounter rejection, misunderstanding, and even bullying, which can leave me feeling isolated. My art becomes a haven from these challenges—a safe haven where I can explore, express, and exist authentically. It is a place where I am not judged, and where my emotions, thoughts, and creativity can flow freely. Through painting, I create a space that is mine alone, where I am not defined by societal norms or limitations.
 
 
 
 This painting reflects my philosophy and process as an artist. Art, to me, is not just a product; it is energy in motion. My work begins with raw, internal energy—emotional, mental, or creative—and transforms into a physical reality on the canvas. It’s a way to translate my inner thoughts and emotions into something tangible that others can perceive and experience. My art is a process of creating something meaningful and objective out of the subjective depths of my inner world.
 
 
 
 I believe that without exploration and a connection to one’s roots, there can be no meaningful destination. This belief shapes my philosophy and my artistic journey. My work embodies the idea of "total direct identification," a concept I hold dear. It is the recognition that the mind’s energy creates everything physical. My art gives authority to the raw origins of thought—the foundational, unfiltered concepts that underpin everything in our reality.
 
 
 
 In this piece, I reflect my sense of shelter in the free-flowing energy of creation. It represents the safe space I find when I’m painting—a space of liberation, fulfillment, and harmony. It’s not just a retreat from external challenges but a space where I can tap into the very essence of existence and share it with the world.
 
 
 
 What does home mean to me? It is where my art is—where my mind, heart, and creativity are free to connect, express, and flourish without fear. This is my shelter, and this is my story.

Title: Wistman's Wood #1 (Dartmoor Series)
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
This photograph is part of a series taken during a recent trip to Wistman’s Wood, one of Britain's last remaining ancient temperate rainforests on Dartmoor, believed to date back to around 7000 BCE.
 
 
 
 Difficult to locate and access, I spent many hours here observing how this site changed with the weather and the emotions it evoked in me—experiencing a strong bodily connection with this ancient, sacred landscape.
 
 
 
 As a Deaf person who was denied access to sign language until I was a teenager, being outside in nature and studying landscapes through my artwork has provided a refuge from the mental health challenges I face as a result of this discrimination—a shelter from my inner storms.
 
 
 
 As I sheltered under the canopy of these trees, escaping the turmoil of a hostile and inaccessible world, I wondered who else had sought refuge and healing here in the centuries before.

Title: Shelter ( paint response)
Content:
This is a piece of work using found pieces of transparent / semi transparent materials leant against the wall to create the simplest form of shelter.
 
 The power is with the hand painted neon pink inside on the wall which acts as warmth, heat, love and protection. The paint conveys basic human needs as well as giving comfort and love from the hand held/ human marks.
 
 Anyone can make a shelter ( children with chairs and sheets) and shelters are being made with basic materials across the world. What unites us is the love and hope and common humanity ( the hand made mark of paint). The paint also symbolises an absence of being.. we know the mark has been made but where is the human: inhabited life?
 
 
 
 This comes with a small uv spot light that shines in to pick out the paint inside. It glows. The live glow seeps out from the edges and we can see it through the different transparencies and materials at the front.
 
 
 
 As the day progresses, the shadows change and move, the colours change. It is not static. And can be put up anywhere.
Other material: Also (optional) uv spot ( currently on the floor shining into the pink).
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
This is a painted response to the theme of shelter as the paint conveys the humanity, the human hand and paint can be used by anyone to express themselves visually.
 
 The light changes by day, during the day and into dusk and night. The uv spot creates an incredible warm, human glow…. I used pink because of the common associations with love, warmth, protection and humanity.
 
 This is a temporary shelter, just found objects ( found different pieces of acrylics) leant against the wall is a basic shelter for any animal or person. We make these shelters as children. Inside it is safe it gives a temporary respite to what is happening outside.
 
 We can enjoy looking at the formal elements and enjoy the magic as it changes as the time, day and place changes too.
 
 This is for everyone, everywhere and exists with hope in a recognised common humanity.

Title: Shelter (City)
Content:
Inspired by the vibrant and intricate aesthetic of Pakistani truck art, and drawing from the artist's unique dual heritage, "Shelter (City)" is a captivating exploration of urban life. This artwork evokes the rich tapestry of experiences that shape an individual growing up in a bustling metropolis, where the influences of music, nature, and culture intertwine.
 
 Emerging from either side of the canvas, imposing yet inviting tower blocks stand as symbols of communal living. These structures, adorned with intricate patterns and vivid colors, transform from mere architectural forms into flourishing ecosystems. They become shelters not only from the elements but also from the monotony of urban existence. Each block is a microcosm of life, pulsating with energy and creativity. The artist's skillful integration of organic and geometric motifs, reminiscent of both natural landscapes and urban infrastructure, creates a dynamic visual language that speaks to the complex relationship between humanity and the built environment.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Inspired by the vibrant and intricate aesthetic of Pakistani truck art, and drawing from the artist's unique dual heritage, "Shelter (City)" is a captivating exploration of urban life. Based of the west end of Newcastle, where magpies are symbolic, and also the nickname given to Geordies.

Title: I ate the swans
Content:
The work was created as part of a residency in the village of Muzychi.
 
 
 
 The text on the artwork: "I ate the swans because they have a
 
 home"
 
 
 
 On the territory of the house in the village of Novosilky, where we lived for two weeks, there was a pond with a small house on the surface of the water for the two swans that lived there. After several days of conscientiously observing these birds, I felt a sense of dissonance between their calmness and my inner emptiness, because they have a home and I don't. I don't have it because it was taken away (I'm talking about Luhansk, occupied in 2014). They, in their close attachment to the place, seemed integral, inextricably linked to the space that surrounded them.
 
 
 
 I was deprived of my home. Now I am looking for a new one. But the feeling that I am in my place is not there, no matter how much I search. Is it even possible to find another home? And if it is, will my old wound ever heal?
 
 
 
 The act of swallowing swans becomes a metaphor for this desire to find a home. Envy of the swans, who have what I lack, makes me want to eat them. Perhaps by absorbing the idyll of those who have not lost their home, I will understand where mine is? This work opened up a new meaning for me: by eating the swans, they settled in me - not finding my home, I became it myself
Other material: Paper, watercolor, ink, acrylic, colored pencils
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This work explores the theme of searching for a sense of belonging and home, the search for a safe place. Through the image of a self-portrait consuming swans, I depict my longing to find what I lack — a home, a familiar place, which I was deprived of in childhood due to the Russian occupation. The swans symbolize attachment to a place, idyll, and belonging, all of which I have lost. By consuming them, I try to understand how to find a new home, and ultimately realize that, even without a physical home, I myself become a shelter — the swans have settled within me.

The creative explorations, investigations, adventures, formed from many found objects. My artistic idea’s, struggles, execution and achievements.

 Demonstration.

 Tended.
 
 Overloaded.

 Uplifted.
 
 This film is a summary of my life here. My shelter studio and workshop. The views, artworks and vista’s it has offered. My shelter as an Outsider’s Inside.

Title: Refuge in the Depths
Content: Refuge in the Depths is my exploration of solitude and sanctuary within the confines of a deep rock chasm. Inspired by the historical and spiritual significance of Lud's Church in Staffordshire, I wanted to create an immersive experience that invites viewers to step into a hidden world of quiet reverence. Using Virtual Reality, I sculpted a 360 degree environment that captures the towering rock walls, the softness of the moss and the dappled light and shadows. For me, this piece is about more than the physical space, its about the emotional refuge that places like this can provide; the comfort, the memories. I wanted to suggest the presence of the medieval community that sought safety and solace here without resorting to the obvious or the cliché. Every detail is meant to evoke that sense of quiet resilience and spiritual depth inviting viewers to reflect on the weight of history and the human need for sanctuary.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Refuge in the Depths explores solitude and sanctuary within a deep rock chasm, inspired by the historical and spiritual essence of Luds Church. Built in Tilt Brush VR, the 360-degree artwork immerses viewers in towering rock walls, mossy textures, and dappled light. It evokes the quiet reverence of medieval congregations who sought solace here. Beyond the VR experience, stills, video, and large-scale projections offer glimpses into this hidden world, emphasizing themes of resilience and sanctuary. The soundscape deepens the emotional and historical connection for viewers. A video could guide viewers through the virtual space, combining visual transitions with ambient soundscapes to evoke the chasm’s historical and spiritual significance. Both formats help convey the artwork’s message to a wider audience, highlighting its emotional depth and narrative elements. *Vimeo link*

Title: Tin Jan: Work and Wheeze (in progress)
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: I've been making artwork since the 1970s about my lived experience as a woman who had had asthma since her babyhood, growing up in the smogs of South East London. Now aged 74, with my health at its worst, I've begun to collate and deepen my collection of life-work. Although my body is 70% medication, I've been protected by the medication, kept alive by it and it's been my 'armour', sheltering me from harm. However, its also been responsible for most of my other conditions - hypertension, diabetes, coeliac disease, arthritis and a stomach that's now risen to my chest cavity squashing my lung (which doesn't work at the best of times). This work illustrates my conditions. The heart is at the centre of this work, because it the heart is full of lovely heroes who have emotionally protected and sheltered me, influenced and brought me joy.

Title: Abode
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
A Section 27 No Fault Eviction launched me into the abyss of flat hunting in a city tha
 
 became 'London by the Sea'. A hard market on its own terms, lacking regulation and
 
 with competition on all levels, becomes my world. My world is precipitated to all
 
 things ‘housing'. I feel vulnerable and un-safe and can get lost in translation with all
 
 the formalities. After a period of housing instability I realise I've lost my home.
 
 'Abode' ignites questions regarding the difference between a 'house' and a 'home', the
 
 latter implying a feeling that's not part of the former'. The first relates to the structura
 
 and formal issues of living in a house such as having furniture. It's needed for a
 
 'home' to exist. Through collage and mixed media, using flat-pack furnitur
 
 instructions, a canvas, textiles and a vacuum storage pack, the work acknowledges
 
 the need for 'home' as well as its complexities

Title: Shelter
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
Going to my woodland is my solace, when I was ill I ran away to my woodlands to get some peace away from hospital. I go camping when I’m there and I sometimes put up hammocks for sleeping in. When I’m there I feel like god is with me in the woods, it is my shelter.
 
 For this sculpture I’ve used hazel from woodlands, willow, hard board and brass. I’ve used a leather tarp with ringlets. This is a representation of me camping. I am the figure under the tarp which is made from keyring holders. The lack of keys represent the fact that I didn’t have or need any keys at this time.

Title: The Medieval Brigand'
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: The artwork represents myself at the age of 20 and the nine years I spent living in a traditional gypsy bender tent whilst travelling the country from county to county harvesting seasonal crops as an itinerant agricultural labourer whilst living in a travelling commune. The artwork includes the entirety of my possessions during this period which consisted mainly of tools and items essential to living in a temporary shelter which would be set up, lived in for a matter of weeks before being taken down, moved and set up again. I constructed the shelter from a frame made of hazel saplings, a plastic tarpaulin was used as a ground sheet with a canvas tarpaulin as a top sheet with another plastic tarpaulin as a top cover. My bed was set atop two pallets and my heat was supplied by a wood burning stove I made from an old oil can.

Title: Reincarnated Unborn Eve'
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: This painting is inspired by becoming a dad. At the time my partner was pregnant and we were both hoping we would have twins. I hoped it would be two boys called Ron and Don. I represented them as two different types of Sun. I believed that would be a way of identifying my two sons through their different brightness and warmth. Both equally as bright but one yellow-gold and the other orange-gold. I represented them as two fire arms, one automatic fire arm and the other a rifle. Representing their quickness as adult men. There is also the fruit that only exists in Sierra Leone, an apple that resembles the Adam’s apple of a man. And a grandfather clock which represents the memories I have of my grandfather, few houses in Sierra Leone still have grandfather clocks in them but they represent masculinity.

Title: Past childhood shelter (Giant in Welsh)
Content: Acrylic paint, pencil and willow charcoal
How it connects to the theme of Shelter: Shelter as a child has different meaning to self as a adult. While exposing my past youth, recall being physcial removed at a very young age from negleted home (shelter) taken into care. It was out of the frying pan into the fire, foster carers homes seemed bleak had to share a bed they did not seem to care and treated us pretty mean or even worse in their homes. Title: Within Our Hands
Other material: Traditional Daub - mainly horse manure (sterilised) with small quantities of horsehair, clay, soil, wood, cement. It may also be treated with a fungicide as a precaution.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
In 2018, a house fire left my family homeless for five years demonstrating the importance of shelter and the precariousness of life without it.
 
Inspired by this, my conceptual artwork explores humanity's basic need for shelter. It demonstrates how ancient techniques, such as daub construction using naturally abundant materials like animal manure, etc can be adapted by Mans creative ingenuity using our uniquely developed hands to create basic shelters. To bridge the gap between ancient and modern methods, I incorporated cement and clay into the daub mixture, which represents contemporary building practices using mortar and brickwork.
 
 The sculpture itself is a pair of hands forming an ancient mud hut-style structure, symbolizing human capacity to shape our environment and create shelter from materials provided by nature. Hands also capable of holding each other in a warm protective embrace

Title: semi-detached
Content: ‘semi-detached’ is a photographic series where artist Meg Mosley presents herself as a solitary woman engaged in domesticity around the home. In this series Meg is focused on bringing cinematic tension to the mundane domestic activities she depicts. Meg sought permission to use the recently vacated 1960’s semi-detached period property after the death of her neighbours. As the building had been a genuine home Meg was able to expose every nuance left behind of a life lived, whilst elaborating on this with her own production design and styling for every room. Meg meticulously planned every camera angle and pose to create nuanced open-ended photographic narratives.
How it connects to the theme of Shelter:
Home is a shelter from storms - all sorts of storms" William L Bennett
 
 In this image I question and bring a tension the notion of home as source of comfort and shelter. Where 'behind closed doors' there can often be an inner, emotional storm brewing. I depict myself as a 1960's housewife alone in the home.
 
 This house belonged to the neighbours of my family home, for over 40 years we shared just a wall between us in our semi-detached homes.
